conclusion: Understanding the problem setup and what needs to be solved.
Figure 1 shows a coil in a radial magnetic field connected to either a constant current source or a resistor.
The mover and coil have combined mass m = 5 kg and accelerate a model aircraft of mass M = 10 kg.
The velocity-time graph in Figure 2 shows the complete motion profile.
We need to find the current I of the constant current source.
During the first phase (0 to t₁), the switch is connected to position 1 (constant current source).
The mover accelerates from rest to v₁ = 80 m/s at t₁ = 1.5 s.
The force causing this acceleration is the Lorentz force on the current-carrying coil.
The Lorentz force on the coil is F = BIL, where B = 0.1 T, I = current, L = total length of the conductor = 100 m.
This force accelerates both the mover+coil (m = 5 kg) and the aircraft (M = 10 kg), so the total mass is 15 kg.
Using Newton's Second Law: F = (m + M)a, where a = Δv/Δt = 80/1.5 = 53.33 m/s².
Therefore: BIL = (m + M)a, leading to 10I = 800, hence I = 80 A.
At t₁, the switch is thrown to position 2 (connecting resistor R₀) and a retraction force F = (800 - 10v) N is applied.
The forces acting on the mover are the retraction force and the electromagnetic force due to the induced current in the coil.
The induced current can be calculated using ε = -BLv, leading to I_induced = ε/R₀ = -BLv/R₀.
The electromagnetic force is F_em = BLI_induced = -B²L²v/R₀ = -10.53v N.
The net force at t₁⁺ is F_net = F + F_em = 800 - 20.53v.
At v₁ = 80 m/s, F_net = 800 - 1642.4 = -842.4 N, indicating deceleration.
